byline.contributor: Rukmini Callimachi reported from Munich, and Melissa Eddy from Berlin. Reporting was contributed by Gregor Aisch and Victor Homola from Berlin; Stefan Pauly and Adam B. Ellick from Munich; Jack Ewing from Locarno, Switzerland; and Sewell Chan from London.
byline.original: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and MELISSA EDDY

abstract: Officials say shooting rampage carried out by Ali Sonboly in Munich, Germany, appears to have no overt links to Islamic State or other terrorist groups or to racial and religious tensions tied to migrant crisis; early evidence points to quietly troubled young man obsessed with school shooting incidents.
lead_paragraph: The motivations of the gunman, an 18-year-old dual German-Iranian citizen, remained unclear. He had been treated for depression and complained of being bullied.

headline.main: Munich Killer Was Troubled, but Had No Terrorist Ties, Germany Says
headline.print_headline: Officials Say No Terrorist Link  Is Found for Munich Gunman

snippet: The motivations of the gunman, an 18-year-old dual German-Iranian citizen, remained unclear. He had been treated for depression and complained of being bullied....
